awd_titl_txt: Integrating Formative Assessment of Computational Thinking with Self-Regulated Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This is a two-year exploratory project submitted to the assessment strand of the Discovery Research PreK-12 (DRK-12) Program, also responsive to NSF 17-149 Dear Colleague Letter: Discovery Research PreK-12: Advancing STEM+Computing. It is aimed at developing, refining, testing, and validating a prototype to illustrate the synergy among formative assessment (FA), computational thinking (CT), and self-regulated learning (SRL) within the discipline of computer science (CS) with teachers (n=10) and students (n=160) in 9th-12th grades. The project will focus on FA, also known as assessment for learning, which generates information that is used for feedback to modify teaching and learning activities. By explicitly eliciting student SRL learning during problem-solving, assessment tasks will illustrate the synergy between FA and SRL. Students will be prompted to analyze a CT task before attempting to solve it, explicitly setting goals, and reflecting on teacher feedback to direct their behaviors towards achieving these goals in subsequent attempts. To elicit SRL behavior, CT task design will follow a three-phase model. Phase 1 will focus on goal setting and task analysis. Phase 2 will focus on self-monitoring during task performance, while Phase 3 will center on reflection. Each task will have two performance iterations, allowing students and teachers to put feedback about prior performance into use. Tasks' content will be drawn from the CS curricula used in secondary school classrooms. They will be validated in authentic classroom contexts in a public school system with a diverse student population. This effort plans to achieve the following outcomes: (1) creation of four prototype CT assessment tasks; (2) development of reliability and validity arguments for the tasks; (3) research into impacts on student CT performance of process-oriented teacher feedback and explicit use of SRL; and (4) development of teacher expertise in FA of CT. 

The project will address two key research questions: (1) Does teacher feedback positively affect student performance when it provides goal-specific feedback on SRL processes, as well as performance outcomes?; and (2) Do students who engage in SRL cycles improve performance on CT tasks, as compared to students who complete tasks without explicit prompts to engage in SRL? To answer these questions, the project will conduct two research studies. The first study will investigate the extent to which teacher feedback on both SRL processes and task performance positively affects student CT achievement, more than outcome-based feedback only. This study will use a quasi-experimental, pre- post-test design with comparison group. Students in the treatment condition will receive feedback on SRL processes and CT task performance. Students in the control condition will receive feedback on performance outcomes only. The second study will investigate the extent to which students who engage in SRL through explicit prompting improve performance on CT tasks, as compared to students without SRL prompts. This study will employ an experimental mixed-model design to examine differences between experimental groups and changes in students' performance over three repeated measurement cycles. The main outcome of this effort will be a prototype illustrating the potential synergies among CT, FA, and SRL which will be used in the future to further research on the intersections among these domains. The tasks developed under this project will be made available online at no cost to the public through multiple practitioner networks. An advisory board and external evaluator will provide feedback and recommendations in regard to the progress and quality of the work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Integrating Formative Assessment of Computational Thinking with Self-Regulated Learning (FA:CT:SRL) project met its goals of supporting teacher professional development (PD) through inquiry learning; creating formative assessment (FA) tasks in computational thinking (CT) embedded in a model of Self-Regulated Learning (SRL); building a validation argument for the use of these tasks; and studying how taking FA:CT:SRL tasks relates to performance in computer science (CS).

We brought a theory-based model of FA of CT to 10 high school classrooms. The schools predominantly served students of color from economically disadvantaged backgrounds in New York City. Six Computer Science: Principles (CS:P) teachers participated in the project throughout its duration. Each had years of CS teaching experience and was active in New York or national CS-education organizations. Each teacher received at least 60 hours of PD that involved problem-based learning in CS, direct and collaborative learning about SRL, and authentic learning through assessment design.

The leadership team, consisting of educational psychologists, CS faculty, and a professional developer, developed a theory-based conceptual model for the formative assessment of computational problem-solving that supported students to improve SRL. We operationalized CT based on both scholarly work and the standards of the Computer Science Teachers Association. Our framework for SRL was derived from a well-researched model focused on 3 stages: Forethought, Performance, and Reflection. Our expert teachers participated at all phases of development.

We developed four CS FA task prototypes according to our model, each designed to be administered at a different point in a high school course of study. Thus, each was aligned to distinct CT concepts and CS:P topics. We designed the tasks for offline (unplugged) administration to ensure they were neutral to variations in computing platform.

We piloted Task 1 in 10 classrooms and 6 schools with approximately 150 students, and used the evidence from the pilot to adjust features for use in Task 2 design. We administered Task 2, and performed a validation study in which we examined student cognitive processes as they completed the task. We found FA of CT, with embedded SRL prompts, elicited cognitive processes aligned with theoretical definitions of the constructs. Among CT practices, testing, debugging, and iteration predominated. Among SRL processes, students engaged most extensively in task analysis, monitoring, and help-seeking. Quantity of SRL processes, timing, and quality of task analysis differentiated students at different levels of mastery.

We tested Task 3 in terms of its FA purpose -- to support student learning -- through an experimental study of the effect of completing an FA with embedded SRL prompts on student learning and SRL. Students (n = 119) were randomly assigned to take a task as designed under our model, or a task identical in content without SRL prompts. We administered two parallel tasks to each group to measure performance change. We found a statistically significant effect where the experimental group showed significant improvement in performance while the control group did not.

Task 4 was completed but not administered due to COVID-19 and restrictions on research with human subjects in schools.

The intellectual merit of FA:CT:SRL in the primary discipline of computer science education lies in the way our work elaborates the intersections of SRL and CT, as it is defined in the CS literature. Our empirical findings highlight the importance of SRL for CT, in particular for debugging and generalization.  Our work also adds to the store of validated FA tools and techniques in CS-education.

The FA:CT:SRL project's intellectual merit beyond the CS discipline lies in the way it makes practical connections between SRL and FA to leverage the power of both to maximize student-level impacts. There is much current interest in learning theory around processes and purposes shared between FA and SRL; we add to this with experimental research about practical, effective methods to combine the two.

Relevant to the field of educational measurement, we demonstrate the use of cognitively-based FA design, as advocated in recent literature. Methodological implications for the field of educational measurement also lie in the way we used think-alouds or cognitive labs as an approach to validation.

As broader impacts, the FA:CT:SRL project resulted in two peer-reviewed journal publications, three national conference presentations, and one book chapter. A cadre of expert teachers shared in dissemination of materials and research through co-authorship in publications. FA:CT:SRL teachers continue to be leaders of CS-education practitioners in NYC and nationally, and to disseminate the materials the team produced. The adaptability of FA:CT:SRL to different curricula, validation evidence in diverse settings, dissemination to wide audiences, and multiple areas of research ensure that the work has broad impacts.
